collection.name: Moving 2D content to a 3D world
collection.description:
The VR/AR web seems to be the latest buzz word in the web community.\n\n At I/O 2016 Google made several big announcements about the technology... Older products and frameworks are still going strong but the competition keeps getting stronger all the time

The most interesting metaphor is how we read online... this goes beyond Nielsen's people only scan online content but tries to answer a more fundamental question of building initerfaces and new metaphors for reading content online. 

Multi platform support is the sticking point for development. 

 None of the big desktop vendors support Mac as a platform for either development or playback. Trying to figure out how much of a sore subject this will become moving forward. None of the major HMD support the Mac as a platform so we can't test those devices for that platform... how do we ensure that our solution displays properly on those devices?  

See Josh Carpenter's [SFHTML5 Presentation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZOaOYTOpwyM) on VR UX/UI from 2015 to provide a contrast to where we are now.  

Possible deliverables may include:  

* Selection of tools and technologies to accomplish the task
* Ideas for how to dusplay 2D content in a 3D environment 
* Code to accomplish this display

collection.name: Progressive and subcompact web reading experiences
collection.description: Project Description
collection.notes: This will take a while... I expect to have code and writing to share relatively soon.

collection.name: eXist Research: Serialized Publications
collection.description:
[eXist](http://exist-db.org/exist/apps/homepage/index.html) seems to be an alternative to Marklogic when it comes to OS X. 

How do you build applications with XML technologies? How is this different than doing an app with Angular/Polymer and MongoDB / MongoLabs

collection.name: Engaged Readers
collection.description:
Based on [Explorable Explanations](http://worrydream.com/ExplorableExplanations/) and [Parable of the Polygons](http://ncase.me/polygons/) research

What would it take to create engaged reading experiences for our readers?\n\nHow does it translate to e-books? To other digital platforms?

collection.name: athena-document
collection.description:
As part of the Athena project, create a markdown document viewer styles with the same options that I want to use for the rest of the project. 

It uses [juicy-markdown](https://github.com/Juicy/juicy-markdown/) for parsing Github Flavored Markdown. It should work with all the GH extensions to Markdown

It uses [Robot Draft](http://www.google.com/fonts/specimen/Roboto+Condensed) for text and headings and [Source Code Pro](http://www.google.com/fonts/specimen/Source+Code+Pro) for code blocks

collection.name: The Trap of CDNs
collection.description: Discusses a particular issue using CDN loaded  resources. When first loading an application

collection.name: ARIA and EPUB Semantics: how much is enough?
collection.description: I'm always researching how to incorporate accessibility elements into my digital content. One of the things we can do is to add semantic elements that will, in theory, make the content more accessible to screen readers.

collection.name: Github as a collaborative publishing tool?
collection.description: Lord of the Files: How GitHub Tamed Free Software (And More) was an article first published in [Wired](http://www.wired.com/2012/02/github-2/all/) in February of 2012. It was an interesting article about a company which work I value enough to pay for the service.

collection.name: Research on digital book metaphors
collection.description: In prior posts I've written about Paged Media and Generated Content for paged media and about creating a print @media style sheet. There is another area I've been researching: how to create a book like experience using only web standards, current or proposed.

collection.name: Long-form publishing
collection.description: Experiments in long-form web publishing using some technologies in the CSS-WG pipeline such as exclusions and regions.

collection.name: Fixed Layout ebook
collection.description:
Fixed Layout creation, including SASS/CSS, 2-page spreads and video.

The repository does not contain all the necessary material or the final product dues to limitations on Github file sizes. The project was created before the introduction of GIT LFS

collection.name: Peter Pan ebook
collection.description: Create an example of a hand coded ebook

collection.name: CSS basic styles for ebooks
collection.description: Experiment with SASS and CSS to create a basic structure for ebook css

collection.name: Python OPF package generator
collection.description:
Implement a basic epub OPF package generator in Python.

The current version is a prototype. There's still a lot of manual work to do after running the script

collection.name: Font subsetting
collection.description: Research tools and techniques for subsetting fonts to reduce file size and comply with some fontsâ€™ license restrictions

collection.name: Synchronized audio books
collection.description: One of the features I like most about ePub 3 is the synchronized books (read aloud) what does it take to create the SMIL file and the content to synchronize with the book? How does it change the way we build ePub content

collection.name: Material Design in Angular  directives
collection.description:
There is a project out that provides material design directives for Angular. What would it take to use them to create the UI for an app? 
  
This is an Angular 1.0 project and hasn't been updated for Angular 2 and it's unlikely that it'll happen... I've settled on Polymer as my framework of choice.

There is a material directive that you can use to build projects in Angular. How well does it work?

**The links need to be updated, the database links will not work**

collection.name: Progressive WordPress
collection.description: The necessary tools and scripts to create a progressive web app based on WordPress blog. This was before Jetpack began working on implementing service workers and other aspects of PWA development

collection.name: PWA Research
collection.description:
Since I'm taking a gig as an instructional designer working in PWAs it's a good idea to start the research ahead of time and start wrapping your head around possible projects and ideas about how to work with this. 
  
It would also help to start outlining some possible evaluation strategies

collection.name: Choice is hard
collection.description: Are we really spoiled by choice when it comes to front-end development?

collection.name: Web Components Deep Dive
collection.description:
Now that Polymer has hit 1.0 it's time to go back and review web components and answer the following questions: **What** are web components? **Why** use web components? **Why not** use web components? **How** to use web components? **Where** to use web components? **How** to build web components? **Should we use** web components now? We will use three different flavors of web components to answer these questions: Vanilla Web components, X-Tags and Polymer 1.0.

Polymer has gone through 2 major releases. It may be time to revisit this again

collection.name: Athena Framework Version 4
collection.description:
Version 4 of Athena Framework. Now that I've learned how to create SPAs with Polymer and now that ServiceWorkers have gained push and notification APIs it's time to revisit Athena and build something closer to what I had in mind when I first envisioned the project.
  
  This version uses GCM as the Push and Notification server and extends the ServiceWorker to act as the GCM client
  
  A tutorial for push and notification is at [http://updates.html5rocks.com/2015/03/push-notificatons-on-the-open-web](http://updates.html5rocks.com/2015/03/push-notificatons-on-the-open-web)

collection.description: Project Description
